CHEMISTRY AT J. H. U.
BY C. E. WATERS.

In these times one almost involuntarily thinks
of war when he hears explosive sounds, so that
to visitors the. Chemical Laboratory may occasionally seem like a miniature bombardment,
especially as the laws of nature and the ideas
of text-book authors ordain that the new students of the science of chemistry are brought
face to face with hydrogen, potassium, chlorate and other explosives at the beginning of
their career. It is apparently a case of the survival of the fittest, for if the student survives he
may become a great chemist. If, when told to
grind together a little sulphur and potassium
chlorate in a mortar, the student takes a teaspoonful of the mixture he is hardly to blame,
because his previous experience with grocery
balances or hay-scales would not lead him to
suppose that a smaller quantity would suffice.
But after he has seen the peaceful grinding instrument suddenly imitating its namesake by
violently hurling the pestle against the ceiling,
he may realize, or at least begin to see, that
an experiment done on a small scale may be instructive. Thus from science he learns the importance of little things and of caution, and his
eyes are opened — by the doctor.
He is told that a mixture of air and hydrogen will explode when a light is brought near it,
so he must wait until all the air has been driven
from his apparatus. Of course, the easiest way
to find out when this has taken place is to apply
a light. From this experiment the thoughtful
student learns that the statement in the books
is a true one, and also that air has a curious
habit of lurking in flasks from which it should
long ago have been expelled. Another important truth is impressed upon him—all things fly
from him who does not wait. But the next

No. 4

time, when he has fixed up new apparatus, he
prefers to wait patiently.
If chemistry taught only caution, and patience, and the importance of little things, the
study of it would be justified. It does still
more. In one experiment there is obtained a
blue liquid which the text-book says is green,
or vice versa. The truly observant student religiously sees whatever color the book says,
and any doubt that may lurk in his mind is
dispelled by cautious glances at the notebooks
of all those around him. Yes, the book says so,
and they all say so—maybe it is my eyes—so
Ile writes"a green solution is formed." Occasional bolder spirits call it a misprint, and say
the solution is blue. These have learned perhaps the most valuable lesson of all—close and
accurate observation. It is, at any rate, the
most difficult to learn, for anyone can afford to
be cautious and wait patiently if by so doing
he can escape bodily harm.
To the world at large and themselves in particular these are the chemists. To another
world belong the workers in the upper regions
who talk so mysteriously of "Carius tubes,"
"combustions," "preparations" and "thesis
work." Freaks are these who cheerfully spend
more than five hours a week in the laboratory,
and who often linger until the stern cry of
"lights out" from " Billy" drives them to
the street. The beginner wonders what sort
of work they can be doing, because he himself
could learn it all in two years, so what's the
good of spending three or four in getting a
Ph. D.?
Seriously, the study of chemistry or of any
other science by college students is not intended as a means of adding to their already heavy
burdens of language and literature, history,
logic, and political economy. Its purpose is to
lighten these burdens by giving variety to their

2

THE NEWS-LETTER.

curriculum, to open their eyes to the greater
world of nature around, to bring them, to a
certain extent, in touch with their fellow-men,
"the workers," who have so much to do with
the practical application of science.
Ever imitative, we all as children passed
through the mud-pie-and-cake stage, producing delicacies far surpassing the best achievements of some celebrated chef. We learned to
read, and then began to walk in divergent
paths. Some as sculptors take nobler material
and still strive to reproduce their ideals. Others, like the writer, lend their ears to the soft,
beguiling words of desperate editors and write
for papers and magazines,articles which they
fondly hope will interest and instruct an eager
multitude of readers. Still others graduate
from mud-pies to making " messes" on the
nursery stove that call down the execrations
of the household. For these there is no hope,
and in time they become chemists. They enter
a world so fascinating that they wonder how
anyone can fail to be interested in their chosen
field. Every living thing, whether plant or
animal, is a laboratory wherein a physicist finds
much to interest him, and at whose threshold
the chemist stands overwhelmed by the complexity and multiplicity of what is there taking
place. Yet everything we can learn, little as it
is, marks an advance toward a better knowledge of our own bodies and of all living nature.
Chemistry and physics thus underlie the study
of biology and of medicine, and physiology ;
while in inanimate nature, whether we study
rocks or clouds, hidden mineral veins or the
remotest stars, some knowledge of these sciences is essential.
And in the commercial
world, in mining and engineering, in electricity,
in manufactures of all kinds, and in a thousand
and one ways, they are called into play.
It is not the object of our compulsory
courses in science to make learned chemists, or
physicists, or biologists. They are intended to
open the eyes of those interested in other lines
of work to some of the commoner and more
important phenomena of nature. It is, to say

the least, quite as fair to make these studies
compulsory as it is to require a certain amount
of works in languages and literature and history of the more scientifically inclined students.
The aim in each case is to broaden the mind
and counteract the tendency towards too great
specialization and narrowness.

DR. KELLY'S GIFT.

Dr. H. A. Kelly, of the Medical School, has
presented the library with a valuable collection
of 257 volumes. It includes a number of noteworthy works, among them the following :
Four early editions of the King James version,
and other editions of the Bible dating from
1534 to 16to ; a collection of classical works,
including early folio editions of Herodotus,
Demosthenes, Acschines, Strabo and Pausanias ; a number of works in classical archwology ; many volumes in English literature,
among which are several editions of Milton,
and especially the beautiful Pickering edition ;
a number of art works, including Digby Wyatt's "Industrial Art," and S. C. Hall's "European Art" ; and several works of reference,
among them Moreri's and Furetiere's Dictionaries. There are also some examples of early
printing, one of which goes back to 1476. In
addition, there is a group of books in ecclesiastical history and theology, including works
by Stillingfleet, Jeremy Taylor, Hooker, and
others, valuable to students of religion and of
language.
The collection as a whole is especially remarkable in the number of bibliographical rarities and finely printed works, and adds much
to our resources in the departments of classical and English literature.

The classes in public speaking are working
at present on Rudyard Kipling's "Recessional."

President Gilman went to New York last
week to visit his brother, who was very ill.
Dr. Greene gave a very enjoyable Chaucer
reading to the Junior class on Thursday evening last week.
Secretary Barr, of the Y. M. C. A., has organized a Bible class for freshmen. It meets

Professor Ira Remsen spent several days of
last week in New Haven, attending the annual
meeting of the American Academy of Sciences,
of which he is secretary.

During the fortnight Dr. Guy Carleton Lee
was sent South by The Sun to write the story
of the rebellious negro. Dr. Lee's correspondence has been given the right of way on the
front columns, and The Sun, which gives
"light for all," editorially speaks of the Doctor as"the distinguished lecturer." This ought
to be gratifying to everybody. Writing from
'Wilmington, North Carolina, Dr. Lee tells of
an armed posse of three thousand men, and
of two rapid-fire guns, costing eighteen hundred dollars, purchased by popular subscription, as a defense for the white man. It would
certainly appear from this that the North Carolina negro is a very bad man. But if it all
stands for thirty years of civilizing influence,
isn't it fair to assume, fair to the negro, that
there is another side of the question not so
zealously exploited by the local journal. We
hope the Doctor will tell us more fully just
what the South has done all these years to educate the head, heart, and hands of these unfortunate subjects of total African depravity.

A cement floor has the desirable virtue of
durability all the year around, and in winter
the added attribute of coldness for the sole of
• the naked foot. The journey these days from
the bath room to one's locker, en deshabille,
calls for the spirit of a Nansen, or an Andree,
and, forsooth, Andree's balloon to sail in would
not be unwelcome. The trustees have never
failed to do anything in their power to bring
comfort to the heart of the athletically inclined
student, and some strips of matting, boards—
anything—placed along the dressing room floor
would now bring comfort to his cold feet.

Continuing the negro question : The Independent (New York) has cut out some novel
and interesting work for Dr. Ballagh. The
Doctor was recently put in print as saying that
the young darkies of today "study the higher
branches, and have a passion for plunging
into Latin, Greek and the sciences," and do not
care, in consequence, to return to farm work
or to become servants, and failing to find professional niches "congregate in the cities and
villages, loaf and get into mischief." The Independent now wants the Doctor to take a census of the Baltimore negro loafers and tell us
what per cent. of them have studied Latin,
Greek and the sciences. And then that journal asks Dr. Ballagh if he cared to return to
farm work or become a servant when he had
got his education

"Football : A Game of Hearts," is the
happy title under which President Thwing of
Western Reserve University tells us why he
believes in the game,"for if football," he says,
trains intellectual alertness and the judgment, it none the less trains the moral nature
of the player." "Pluck, enthusiasm, self-restraint, are elements of the heart which are
trained in football." And the Doctor might
0, we have
well have added " humility."
learned that, sons of Hopkins ! Do you remember (can you forget?) how once upon a
time we all went out clothed in the purple of
our pride ? For had we not a mighty team,
verily a mighty team ! Had we not whitewashed everything in sight ! But the mutes !
0, Gallaudet ! Four minutes play, and a
touchdown ! another, then another ! and an—.
"How are the mighty fallen !" We went
home after awhile, pondering on the wisdom
of the poet-king : "Pride goeth before destruction, and an haughty spirit before a fall."
Yes, it is "A game of hearts," and sometimes
humbled hearts.

ATHLETICS.
FOOT BALL.
GALLAUDET 28—HOPKINS 0.

With the loss of the Gallaudet game on November 12 we practically lost the State championship. A large crowd, for Hopkins, came
out to see the game. They knew that Gallaudet had a strong team and expected to see a
hard-fought battle. What they did see was
one of the poorest exhibitions of football ever
put up by a Hopkins team. There seemed to
be no head to the team ; team work was utterly lacking ; the backs stumbled over each
other, and were slow in starting. Captain Robinson did not seem to know how to get effective
work out of his men. McFarland several times
made wide openings in the line, but no use
was made of them.
Two or three men did what could be called
tackling ; the rest seemed to dive at a man's
feet, and, of course, miss him every time. The
most noticeable fault was fumbling. It is one
of the first principles of the game to learn to
catch the ball, yet the Hopkins men fumbled
again and again, losing the ball at the most
critical times. The ends played fairly well at
times, but the right end was very weak in
breaking up the interference that came his way.
With all these faults several men did creditable work for the Black and Blue. Hancock,
Stewart, McFarland and Sayler played well,
and if they had been supported properly the
result might have been different.
Gallaudet played an excellent game. It
seemed a perfect game in comparison with
Hopkins. Their team work was of the highest
type, and their interference remarkable. The
best play of the game was made by Waters,
Gallaudet's fullback, who broke through the
Hopkins line, made an eighty-five-yard run,
and scored a touchdown. Among the other
Gallaudet players who deserve praise for their
excellent work are : Andree, right halfback,
and Baumgartner, quarter-back.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
THE ST. JOHN'S GAtIE.

ST. JOHN'S 6-HOPKINS o.
In a close and exciting contest at Annapolis
last Saturday, Hopkins lost the final game of
the season. Although the team was crippled
by the absence of McFarland and Lindley, and
somewhat disheartened, possibly, by the defeat of last Saturday, they played a hard and
plucky game. The slippery field was also
against us, for Hopkins' practice has been indoors on a hard, smooth surface, with no opportunity for the mud-horse training to be gotten out of doors. There was a decided lack
of team work in the band of rooters that
went down with the team. About thirty men
were there, including the chief rooter, who
was not much in evidence at the time of need.
St. John's kicked off, and it was Hopkins'
ball on her ten-yard line. After a few plays,
during which the ball changed hands more
than once, Guggenheimer made a fifty-yard
run, but Hopkins lost the ball. St. John's now
rushed the ball steadily down the field, and
finally carried it over the line, but as the ball
was dropped and Stewart fell on it, a touchback resulted. It was Hopkins' ball on her
twenty-five yard line. St. John's got the ball
on downs, but fumbled badly and lost it while
trying for a kick. The ball changed hands several times, and at the close of the half was in
our territory.
In the second half, Stewart kicked off. Hopkins got the ball, but lost it again on our twenty-five yard line. Bull was injured and Smith
took his place. We got the ball, faked a kick,
and Williams, St. John's quarter-back, made
a pretty tackle.
Then the ball came perilously near our goal,
and Stewart kicked out of bounds. Our team
held nobly, but at last Sinclair scored for St.
John's, and goal was kicked.
Score-6-o.
In the few minutes that remained Hopkins
tried hard to tie the score, and when time was
called had the ball one yard from St. John's
goal. The game was hotly contested through-

7

out, and our team played well. Although we
were defeated, when all the circumstances are
considered, the game goes far toward retrieving the poor showing made against Gallaudet.

ATHLETIC ITETIS.

Among the Hopkins men who attended the
Yale-Princeton football game were J. Girvin
Peters, Stephen Harwood, K. Jungbluth, M.
Jungbluth, Leonard Mackall and Charles Vogeler. A large delegation from the Medical
School also saw the game.
The outlook for track athletics this year is
very promising. All the old men, with the exception of Smith (Igoo) and Talty ('99), have
returned. Much is expected of the new men,
among whom there are several promising candidates. The Medical School has received some
notable additions, F. T. Riggs, a very fast man
in the 220 ; Alfred Karsted, a quarter man
from Leland Stanford, and John Auver, a fast
man in the sprints. Captain Mullen and Coach
Mackdermott prophesy a very strong team.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
UNIVERSITY NEWS.
The Musical Association will give four entertainments this season, following the plan
used last year. Chamber music will be provided for three of these, under the direction of
Mr. W. E. Heimendahl. One evening will be
devoted to an exhibition of modern acoustics
by Dr. Ames. Only persons enrolled in the
University register are eligible to membership,
which may be secured by applying to the registrar. The first concert will be given in McCoy Hall Saturday, December bo, at 8 r. M.
Mr. John R. Mott, the organizer and general
secretary of the World's Student Federation
of Associations, will address the Y. M. C. A.
on their anniversary November 29. Mr.-Mott
has a wide reputation and should be greeted by
a large audience.
The second annual meeting of the Maryland
Conference of Charities and Correction will
be held at the University on Tuesday and
Wednesday, November 29 and 30. Several
prominent Baltimoreans and some Hopkins
men will speak.
The Baltimore Chess Club is arranging a
series of match games between local clubs.
Hopkins is included in the list. Last winter our
chess enthusiasts played a series of games with
the Baltimore Chess Club, and made a fair
showing against older and more experienced
players.

CHEMISTRY AT J. H. U.
BY C. E. WATERS.

In these times one almost involuntarily thinks
of war when he hears explosive sounds, so that
to visitors the. Chemical Laboratory may occasionally seem like a miniature bombardment,
especially as the laws of nature and the ideas
of text-book authors ordain that the new students of the science of chemistry are brought
face to face with hydrogen, potassium, chlorate and other explosives at the beginning of
their career. It is apparently a case of the survival of the fittest, for if the student survives he
may become a great chemist. If, when told to
grind together a little sulphur and potassium
chlorate in a mortar, the student takes a teaspoonful of the mixture he is hardly to blame,
because his previous experience with grocery
balances or hay-scales would not lead him to
suppose that a smaller quantity would suffice.
But after he has seen the peaceful grinding instrument suddenly imitating its namesake by
violently hurling the pestle against the ceiling,
he may realize, or at least begin to see, that
an experiment done on a small scale may be instructive. Thus from science he learns the importance of little things and of caution, and his
eyes are opened — by the doctor.
He is told that a mixture of air and hydrogen will explode when a light is brought near it,
so he must wait until all the air has been driven
from his apparatus. Of course, the easiest way
to find out when this has taken place is to apply
a light. From this experiment the thoughtful
student learns that the statement in the books
is a true one, and also that air has a curious
habit of lurking in flasks from which it should
long ago have been expelled. Another important truth is impressed upon him—all things fly
from him who does not wait. But the next

No. 4

time, when he has fixed up new apparatus, he
prefers to wait patiently.
If chemistry taught only caution, and patience, and the importance of little things, the
study of it would be justified. It does still
more. In one experiment there is obtained a
blue liquid which the text-book says is green,
or vice versa. The truly observant student religiously sees whatever color the book says,
and any doubt that may lurk in his mind is
dispelled by cautious glances at the notebooks
of all those around him. Yes, the book says so,
and they all say so—maybe it is my eyes—so
Ile writes"a green solution is formed." Occasional bolder spirits call it a misprint, and say
the solution is blue. These have learned perhaps the most valuable lesson of all—close and
accurate observation. It is, at any rate, the
most difficult to learn, for anyone can afford to
be cautious and wait patiently if by so doing
he can escape bodily harm.
To the world at large and themselves in particular these are the chemists. To another
world belong the workers in the upper regions
who talk so mysteriously of "Carius tubes,"
"combustions," "preparations" and "thesis
work." Freaks are these who cheerfully spend
more than five hours a week in the laboratory,
and who often linger until the stern cry of
"lights out" from " Billy" drives them to
the street. The beginner wonders what sort
of work they can be doing, because he himself
could learn it all in two years, so what's the
good of spending three or four in getting a
Ph. D.?
Seriously, the study of chemistry or of any
other science by college students is not intended as a means of adding to their already heavy
burdens of language and literature, history,
logic, and political economy. Its purpose is to
lighten these burdens by giving variety to their

2

THE NEWS-LETTER.

curriculum, to open their eyes to the greater
world of nature around, to bring them, to a
certain extent, in touch with their fellow-men,
"the workers," who have so much to do with
the practical application of science.
Ever imitative, we all as children passed
through the mud-pie-and-cake stage, producing delicacies far surpassing the best achievements of some celebrated chef. We learned to
read, and then began to walk in divergent
paths. Some as sculptors take nobler material
and still strive to reproduce their ideals. Others, like the writer, lend their ears to the soft,
beguiling words of desperate editors and write
for papers and magazines,articles which they
fondly hope will interest and instruct an eager
multitude of readers. Still others graduate
from mud-pies to making " messes" on the
nursery stove that call down the execrations
of the household. For these there is no hope,
and in time they become chemists. They enter
a world so fascinating that they wonder how
anyone can fail to be interested in their chosen
field. Every living thing, whether plant or
animal, is a laboratory wherein a physicist finds
much to interest him, and at whose threshold
the chemist stands overwhelmed by the complexity and multiplicity of what is there taking
place. Yet everything we can learn, little as it
is, marks an advance toward a better knowledge of our own bodies and of all living nature.
Chemistry and physics thus underlie the study
of biology and of medicine, and physiology ;
while in inanimate nature, whether we study
rocks or clouds, hidden mineral veins or the
remotest stars, some knowledge of these sciences is essential.
And in the commercial
world, in mining and engineering, in electricity,
in manufactures of all kinds, and in a thousand
and one ways, they are called into play.
It is not the object of our compulsory
courses in science to make learned chemists, or
physicists, or biologists. They are intended to
open the eyes of those interested in other lines
of work to some of the commoner and more
important phenomena of nature. It is, to say

the least, quite as fair to make these studies
compulsory as it is to require a certain amount
of works in languages and literature and history of the more scientifically inclined students.
The aim in each case is to broaden the mind
and counteract the tendency towards too great
specialization and narrowness.

DR. KELLY'S GIFT.

Dr. H. A. Kelly, of the Medical School, has
presented the library with a valuable collection
of 257 volumes. It includes a number of noteworthy works, among them the following :
Four early editions of the King James version,
and other editions of the Bible dating from
1534 to 16to ; a collection of classical works,
including early folio editions of Herodotus,
Demosthenes, Acschines, Strabo and Pausanias ; a number of works in classical archwology ; many volumes in English literature,
among which are several editions of Milton,
and especially the beautiful Pickering edition ;
a number of art works, including Digby Wyatt's "Industrial Art," and S. C. Hall's "European Art" ; and several works of reference,
among them Moreri's and Furetiere's Dictionaries. There are also some examples of early
printing, one of which goes back to 1476. In
addition, there is a group of books in ecclesiastical history and theology, including works
by Stillingfleet, Jeremy Taylor, Hooker, and
others, valuable to students of religion and of
language.
The collection as a whole is especially remarkable in the number of bibliographical rarities and finely printed works, and adds much
to our resources in the departments of classical and English literature.

The classes in public speaking are working
at present on Rudyard Kipling's "Recessional."

During the fortnight Dr. Guy Carleton Lee
was sent South by The Sun to write the story
of the rebellious negro. Dr. Lee's correspondence has been given the right of way on the
front columns, and The Sun, which gives
"light for all," editorially speaks of the Doctor as"the distinguished lecturer." This ought
to be gratifying to everybody. Writing from
'Wilmington, North Carolina, Dr. Lee tells of
an armed posse of three thousand men, and
of two rapid-fire guns, costing eighteen hundred dollars, purchased by popular subscription, as a defense for the white man. It would
certainly appear from this that the North Carolina negro is a very bad man. But if it all
stands for thirty years of civilizing influence,
isn't it fair to assume, fair to the negro, that
there is another side of the question not so
zealously exploited by the local journal. We
hope the Doctor will tell us more fully just
what the South has done all these years to educate the head, heart, and hands of these unfortunate subjects of total African depravity.

A cement floor has the desirable virtue of
durability all the year around, and in winter
the added attribute of coldness for the sole of
• the naked foot. The journey these days from
the bath room to one's locker, en deshabille,
calls for the spirit of a Nansen, or an Andree,
and, forsooth, Andree's balloon to sail in would
not be unwelcome. The trustees have never
failed to do anything in their power to bring
comfort to the heart of the athletically inclined
student, and some strips of matting, boards—
anything—placed along the dressing room floor
would now bring comfort to his cold feet.

ATHLETICS.
FOOT BALL.
GALLAUDET 28—HOPKINS 0.

With the loss of the Gallaudet game on November 12 we practically lost the State championship. A large crowd, for Hopkins, came
out to see the game. They knew that Gallaudet had a strong team and expected to see a
hard-fought battle. What they did see was
one of the poorest exhibitions of football ever
put up by a Hopkins team. There seemed to
be no head to the team ; team work was utterly lacking ; the backs stumbled over each
other, and were slow in starting. Captain Robinson did not seem to know how to get effective
work out of his men. McFarland several times
made wide openings in the line, but no use
was made of them.
Two or three men did what could be called
tackling ; the rest seemed to dive at a man's
feet, and, of course, miss him every time. The
most noticeable fault was fumbling. It is one
of the first principles of the game to learn to
catch the ball, yet the Hopkins men fumbled
again and again, losing the ball at the most
critical times. The ends played fairly well at
times, but the right end was very weak in
breaking up the interference that came his way.
With all these faults several men did creditable work for the Black and Blue. Hancock,
Stewart, McFarland and Sayler played well,
and if they had been supported properly the
result might have been different.
Gallaudet played an excellent game. It
seemed a perfect game in comparison with
Hopkins. Their team work was of the highest
type, and their interference remarkable. The
best play of the game was made by Waters,
Gallaudet's fullback, who broke through the
Hopkins line, made an eighty-five-yard run,
and scored a touchdown. Among the other
Gallaudet players who deserve praise for their
excellent work are : Andree, right halfback,
and Baumgartner, quarter-back.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
THE ST. JOHN'S GAtIE.

ST. JOHN'S 6-HOPKINS o.
In a close and exciting contest at Annapolis
last Saturday, Hopkins lost the final game of
the season. Although the team was crippled
by the absence of McFarland and Lindley, and
somewhat disheartened, possibly, by the defeat of last Saturday, they played a hard and
plucky game. The slippery field was also
against us, for Hopkins' practice has been indoors on a hard, smooth surface, with no opportunity for the mud-horse training to be gotten out of doors. There was a decided lack
of team work in the band of rooters that
went down with the team. About thirty men
were there, including the chief rooter, who
was not much in evidence at the time of need.
St. John's kicked off, and it was Hopkins'
ball on her ten-yard line. After a few plays,
during which the ball changed hands more
than once, Guggenheimer made a fifty-yard
run, but Hopkins lost the ball. St. John's now
rushed the ball steadily down the field, and
finally carried it over the line, but as the ball
was dropped and Stewart fell on it, a touchback resulted. It was Hopkins' ball on her
twenty-five yard line. St. John's got the ball
on downs, but fumbled badly and lost it while
trying for a kick. The ball changed hands several times, and at the close of the half was in
our territory.
In the second half, Stewart kicked off. Hopkins got the ball, but lost it again on our twenty-five yard line. Bull was injured and Smith
took his place. We got the ball, faked a kick,
and Williams, St. John's quarter-back, made
a pretty tackle.
Then the ball came perilously near our goal,
and Stewart kicked out of bounds. Our team
held nobly, but at last Sinclair scored for St.
John's, and goal was kicked.
Score-6-o.
In the few minutes that remained Hopkins
tried hard to tie the score, and when time was
called had the ball one yard from St. John's
goal. The game was hotly contested through-

7

out, and our team played well. Although we
were defeated, when all the circumstances are
considered, the game goes far toward retrieving the poor showing made against Gallaudet.

ATHLETIC ITETIS.

Among the Hopkins men who attended the
Yale-Princeton football game were J. Girvin
Peters, Stephen Harwood, K. Jungbluth, M.
Jungbluth, Leonard Mackall and Charles Vogeler. A large delegation from the Medical
School also saw the game.
The outlook for track athletics this year is
very promising. All the old men, with the exception of Smith (Igoo) and Talty ('99), have
returned. Much is expected of the new men,
among whom there are several promising candidates. The Medical School has received some
notable additions, F. T. Riggs, a very fast man
in the 220 ; Alfred Karsted, a quarter man
from Leland Stanford, and John Auver, a fast
man in the sprints. Captain Mullen and Coach
Mackdermott prophesy a very strong team.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
UNIVERSITY NEWS.
The Musical Association will give four entertainments this season, following the plan
used last year. Chamber music will be provided for three of these, under the direction of
Mr. W. E. Heimendahl. One evening will be
devoted to an exhibition of modern acoustics
by Dr. Ames. Only persons enrolled in the
University register are eligible to membership,
which may be secured by applying to the registrar. The first concert will be given in McCoy Hall Saturday, December bo, at 8 r. M.
Mr. John R. Mott, the organizer and general
secretary of the World's Student Federation
of Associations, will address the Y. M. C. A.
on their anniversary November 29. Mr.-Mott
has a wide reputation and should be greeted by
a large audience.
The second annual meeting of the Maryland
Conference of Charities and Correction will
be held at the University on Tuesday and
Wednesday, November 29 and 30. Several
prominent Baltimoreans and some Hopkins
men will speak.
The Baltimore Chess Club is arranging a
series of match games between local clubs.
Hopkins is included in the list. Last winter our
chess enthusiasts played a series of games with
the Baltimore Chess Club, and made a fair
showing against older and more experienced
players.
